headline.main: An Economy in Need of Holistic Medicine

docs.snippet: What can the so-called wellness approach to health tell us about our present economic malady?

docs.lead_paragraph: It is well known that during the nation's gale-force recession, many older Americans who dreamed of retirement continued to work, often because their 401(k)'s had plunged in value. In fact, there are more Americans 65 and older in the job market today than at any time in history, 6.6 million, compared with 4.1 million in 2001.
docs.abstract: More Americans 65 and older are working than ever; there are 6.6 million such workers compared with 4.1 million in 2001; nearly 500,000 workers 65 and older want to work but cannot find jobs; unemployment rate for older workers is 6.7 percent, more than double rate of 2007; graphs; photos (M)
docs.snippet: It is well known that during the nation's gale-force recession, many older Americans who dreamed of retirement continued to work, often because their 401(k)'s had plunged in value.     In fact, there are more Americans 65 and older in the job market...

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans without health insurance are less likely to know if they have diabetes or high cholesterol than those with coverage, and they are less likely to keep their high blood pressure under control than the insured, a new study reports. The researchers used national health survey data to look at three chronic but manageable health conditions -- diabetes, hypertension and high cholesterol -- that can lead to serious long-term complications often treated at public expense and thus contributing to overall health care costs.
docs.abstract: Researchers say that Americans without health insurance are less likely to know if they have diabetes, high cholesterol or high blood pressure; photo (S)
docs.snippet: Americans without health insurance are less likely to know if they have diabetes or high cholesterol than those with coverage, and they are less likely to keep their high blood pressure under control than the insured, a new study reports.     The...

docs.lead_paragraph: Arthur Ullian is president of the National Council on Spinal Cord Injury and co-author of a coming analysis in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences on the economic benefits of a health care overhaul. Mr. Ullian spoke with Anne Underwood, a freelance writer, and the following is an excerpt: QUESTION. The Congressional Budget Office projects costs of around $800 billion over 10 years for the Senate Finance Committee bill.
docs.abstract: Excerpt from freelance writer Anne Underwood's interview with Arthur Ullian, president of National Council on Spinal Cord Injury, on economic benefits of health care overhaul (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Most people choose more insurance than they really need,'' said Randall Abbott, a benefits consultant at Watson Wyatt. Such overstuffed choices may have been fine back when premiums were low. But in the last 10 years, the contributions of workers for family health insurance coverage have risen 128 percent -- from just $1,543 a year in 1999, to $3,515 in 2009, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation.

docs.lead_paragraph: It is well known that during the nation's gale-force recession, many older Americans who dreamed of retirement continued to work, often because their 401(k)'s had plunged in value. In fact, there are more Americans 65 and older in the job market today than at any time in history, 6.6 million, compared with 4.1 million in 2001.
docs.snippet: Nearly half a million people 65 and older want to work but cannot find a job, this group’s highest unemployment level since the Great Depression.

docs.lead_paragraph: Anybody watching the Yankee-Angels series understands the home field advantage. He who bats last often laughs last. Jockeying for the same sort of edge is going on in the Senate right now in the debate over whether to add a government-run insurance plan to the big health care legislation.
docs.abstract: Supporters of public option want it in Senate health care bill at outset, meaning opponents would need 60 votes to pass amendment stripping it out; opponents want to leave government plan out of bill, so that supporters would need 60 votes to add it (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Wading into the health care debate, First Lady Michelle Obama said on Friday that a health care overhaul would ease the struggles faced by women with breast cancer.

headline.main: First Lady Talks About Breast Cancer

docs.abstract: Michelle Obama says the current health care system does not work for many breast cancer patients.
